3:44 - your use of the Mercator projection is diabolically bad, I'm sad to say.
Mercator is a sailing map whose intention is to allow for navigation by sea - nothing more.
It massively deforms the sizes of land masses. It is utterly and totally inappropriate for ANY scientific use.
For example, the tiny landmass of Greenland looks the same size as South America, whereas in reality it is 1/9th the size.
Mercator despicably enlarges landmass size the further North or South you go.
And so you saying "1/5th the landmass" while showing us a Mercactor map is physically misleading. So much for physics!

If you want to refer to land area, then you should be using a Peters Projection, as this map shows every land area correctly in size! Necessarily it does deform the shape of a country or landmass, but the shape is much less important that the idea of equal-area!

I'm only giving you 6/10 for this one, because maps are very important to the way humanity views our globe - and the Mercator has warped and twisted our view of the Earth for far too long. It should NEVER have been adopted as a reference map, and its use should have been restricted to ocean navigation only.

In 1985 my college physics professor told us about global warming. My Pakistani lab partner in 1988 asked if May was always 80 degrees. No, I told him it was global warming.

I was growing big, juicy tomatos as late as November as global warming pushed our first frost/snow from Halloween to November 5th or so.

Basically, we had two growing seasons. Hence the 3 billion more people.

Well, 30 years later, the Spring of 2017, May started getting colder and colder, as did April and March. Our last frost was May 12 in 2021. It was May 5 in n 2020. Each year it moved about a week, for a total of 6 weeks in Spring.. Same in Autumn. That's 12 more weeks of cold, miserable, and sometimes freezing, weather for the year

Our growing season grew shorter and shorter. My cousins' farms were lucky to have a crop that wasn't frozen to death after planting. They planted different crops, about 2 weeks apart. One got frozen, the other did not.

Imagine how desperately cold it would have been these last 6 years had the previous 30 years not seen some warming.

We would have had Winter in Summer. Remember Krakatoa? Snow was recorded in June by Jefferson, as I recall.

The Autumn of 2021 was the first warm Autumn since 2016. I hope this May starts to warm up. We've had it slightly warmer than last year, no frost yet. We'll see.

The permafrost they have to be really concerned about is the stuff on the ocean floor. The ice there tends to be a methane clathrate and it's extremely fragile and sensitive to temperature changes. If that starts to melt, we're in serious trouble. Worldwide, there's more than enough methane clathrate to reproduce the PETM (Palaeocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum). In other words, an 8-12C rise in global temps. Even though methane only has a short life in the atmosphere, it's the extra CO2 that gets outgassed that's the long term worry. CO2 has a long latency in the atmosphere (100-1000 years) and after the methane does its trick, the CO2 will linger for a long time and do even more damage. That's why the PETM lasted so long, the CO2 levels were up around 800-1200ppm for over 100K years. How that would affect the modern world as far as the climate and such goes is up for debate, as the circumstances the world was in back then are different to now. Sea levels were higher then and the world was warmer to begin with. The geography/geology of the planet was also different. So, how all that extra GHG would react to the present situation is still a matter of research. In any case, though, if it were to occur it would be an utter disaster. However, it has to be taken into consideration, since we're going to be the ones driving such a situation. So, if it does happen, it'll be a lot quicker than the previous, natural processes which drove it.

It's not a positive feedback loop when plants require carbon to live and they reproduce. If there were no plant life removing carbon from the atmosphere, then you could make that case. Besides, the Earth has already been much hotter and had more carbon dioxide provably at least 5x in the past and there was no runaway feedback loop.

Permafrost has been rapidly melting on Earth for about 23,000 years. This landscape is readily visible on satellite photo.

For example, look up the Yamal Peninsula on Google Maps or Earth. The round lakes that cover the landscape are called pingos, they form from melting permafrost. These pingos are present far south into Kazakhstan down to about 52 degrees latitude, the extent of permafrost during the last glacial maximum 23,000 years ago.

Good video, with lots of information. However, it only appears to be one sided, from the perspective of how much harm melting permafrost will cause. There does not appear to be any effort to demonstrate the benefits of melting permafrost. Melting permafrost means more arable lands, which in turn increases the carrying capacity of the planet. In Alaska alone the number of farms has doubled between 1992 and 2022. There has been an agricultural boom occurring in Canada, Russia, Finland, Sweden, and Norway - everywhere the permafrost is melting. Even though the population of the planet has more than doubled since the 1950s, we no longer see the famines that regularly plagued Africa during that time. Literally millions are alive today that wouldn't have been otherwise, thanks entirely to a warming planet.

There was only one minor issue with this video, near the beginning when referencing the "last ice-age." The current ice-age, the fifth in Earth's history, a.k.a. the Quaternary Ice-Age, began 2.58 million years ago and is still on-going. We just happen to be enjoying one of the brief interglacial periods during the current ice-age. What she was actually referring to was the last period of glaciation, which started 115,000 years ago and ended 15,000 years ago. The current Holocene Interglacial began 11,700 years ago at the end of the Younger Dryas.

I can tell you what permafrost is with simple logic. As the earth warms up to a point where evaporation becomes super saturated and the winter sets in it dumps so much snow on the ground to which the earth can not melt it back. This is what we call the start of the ice age. You will still have hot days on earth yet in the north this freezes over. Once this cycle slows down and all of that snow melts down you end up with a very swampy area with lots of lakes, rivers, ponds, swamps. As the ice age comes again it will freeze many of these water logged areas and create permafrost.Every year some sort of planet, tree or organic thing builds a layer over the permafrost which then insulates its. Over thousands of years enough dirt and material collected from the rains, winds and growth cause the build up of material over the permafrost. During these cycles more water logged areas become permafrost in the winter and as growing season come around they freeze over again. 50 thousand years of doing this creates permafrost.

Since the beginning of 2021, 23 resolutions have been passed by local governments in Virginia to condemn China’s forced organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience, mostly Falun Gong practitioners. Essex County, Staunton City and Fluvanna County are the latest government bodies to pass such resolutions.

The resolution passed unanimously by the Fluvanna County Board of Supervisors on November 3, 2021, reminded its citizens that they may become accomplices in killing innocent lives if they go to China for organ transplants.

The resolution says, “extensive and credible reports have revealed mass killing of prisoners of conscience in the People's Republic of China, primarily practitioners of the Chinese spiritual practice of Falun Gong, but also other religious and ethnic minority groups, in order to obtain organs for transplants.”

For a good portion of the last 2.5 million years the permafrost front was way, way farther south into Europe, Asia and North America, as in well into what is now the United States. During that time the ice sheets and the permafrost have advanced and retreated many times. Given that, for the last couple of millions of years, it is normal for the northern continents to be largely covered in a couple of miles of ice, what is the disaster? For the ice sheets with their arctic conditions covering most of the northern world? Or for their retreat with the thawing of the accompanying permafrost that extended well south of the ice sheets and release of carbon and settling of the land that goes along with thawing? As humans weren't around until the last little while, what was the cause of the freezing and thawing? If, for almost all of the last 100 million years there was NO permanent ice on the plant, what is normal? Were either no ice at all or a great deal of ice covering a large area of the land disasters? Were sea levels 400 ft. lower than now (a fair share of the last couple of millions of years) or 200 to 300 feet higher than now (most of the last 100 million and more years) a disaster? What is "normal" CO2 levels, global temperatures, ice coverage and sea level? The answer is not, "Why, what it is today because I am alive and seeing it" or "It didn't happen if there are no photos of it." Between global warming and global cooling, I wall take warming every time. A lot less starvation of everything from humans through field mice and beyond.

Thank you for the video. Atmospheric CO2 levels lack the temperature forcing leverage to steer climate. Using rough math estimates atmospheric CO2 is less than 1/2% on average of the temperature forcing effect in earth's atmosphere. A recent paper on Arctic warming proposes the Atlantic Ocean's warmer waters have been increasingly migrating into the Arctic Ocean razing the temperature of the Arctic Ocean over the last 120 years. Ocean water heat is a huge climate steering force and does have the leverage to create the warming effects in this video. That doesn't mean that is the primary cause, but it is a mechanism with the overwhelming temperature forcing leverage needed to warm the Arctic.  

About 1% of the troposphere is water vapor.  Water vapor has a CO2e of 18. Water vapor H2O gas is considered 18 times more powerful as a greenhouse gas temperature forcing agent than CO2. Tropospheric water vapor is not adequately accounted for in the United Nation's International Panel on Climate Change reports. Water vapor varies greatly in the troposphere (lower atmosphere) from nearly zero in Antartica in the winter time to a little over 4% when 100% humidity at 30°C (86°F).  

Treating CO2 and H2O gasses as ideal gasses, which H2O is not, but it is close enough to show how impossible it is for CO2 to play any serious role in atmospheric temperature forcing, tropospheric water vapor is 25 times (1% H2O gas / 0.04% CO2 = 25) more present than all the CO2 in earth's atmosphere. With a CO2e of 18 this means tropospheric water vapor is 450 times (18 X 25) more of a temperature forcing agent in earth's atmosphere than all the CO2 in earth's atmosphere. All the other greenhouse gasses add up together to be less than temperature forcing effect of atmospheric CO2.  Giving all the other greenhouse gases a sum total temperature forcing effect the same as CO2, which they are actually less, provides a result of CO2e of 450 tropospheric water vapor + 1 CO2 + 1 other greenhouse gasses for a total of 452 CO2e. From this total CO2's leverage as a temperature forcing greenhouse gas in earth's atmosphere is 1/452 or 0.221% or less than 1/4%. Since water vapor varies greatly in the troposphere and H2O is far from an idea gas stating CO2 is less than 1/2% of the temperature forcing effect in earth's atmosphere is likely to remain true when degrading the less than 1/4% results due more accurate methods and lower water vapor. These calculations do not include stratospheric water vapor, which can have little effect on warming the earth or the water vapor from the burning of fossil fuels.

The water vapor from the burning of fossil fuels for the period it is in the atmosphere has a greater greenhouse gas temperature forcing effect than the CO2 placed in the atmosphere from the burning of the same fossil fuels that produced the water vapor. The water vapor in IPCC reports appears to only be stratospheric water (the stratosphere contains nearly zero water vapor) and the water vapor from the burning of fossil fuels. From an engineering perspective it is likely more insightful to think of the earth's warming as ocean warming.

Atmospheric CO2 at levels of 10 to 40 ppm is thought to be at saturation for converting high energy ultraviolet radiation high up in the stratosphere into lower frequencies better able to warm the earth. CO2's ultra violet energy conversion to lower frequencies is thought to be responsible for 50°C of earth's warming. Without this warming earth would be a snow ball and has been in the past. This is not a greenhouse gas effect.

As a scientist and physicist, you must surely know that the carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere has very little to do with anthropogenic sources but rather under Henry's Law the partial pressure balance between carbon dioxide in the oceans and that in the atmosphere with the former 1000 times the amount as in the latter. This release depends on ocean temperature which depends on solar input and there can be a lag of hundreds of years between the solar input and the rise in surface temperature due to ocean currents like the Humbolt that determines the El Nino/La Nian cycle that determines atmospheric temperature. With the oceans covering 70% of the planet and only 3000 Argo buoys measuring its temperature profile and only since 2002 the claimed link between atmospheric carbon dioxide and so-called global warming is only that, an unproven claim with most of the increase in land temperatures taken from compromised sites like airports really measuring the increase in the contribution from urban heat islands. Global temperature goes in cycles ranging from the 150-year warming cycle now ending to cycles of 5000 years so your statement " as temperatures continue to rise" is unscientific and untrue. Hey Dianna! Love your videos. Just wanted to mention, that's not what "begs the question" means -- it's a commonly misused phrase which actually refers to a logical fallacy wherein you basically presuppose a conclusion in making your argument i.e. circular reasoning or petitio principii. Although that doesn't keep most people from using it in this exact same sense!

What you meant to say was e.g. "raises the question" or "brings about the question", something like that.

(Although by this point, considering that it's one of those phrases that is 'misused' more frequently than it is used 'correctly', there's certainly a reasonably strong argument to be made for updating the definition to include the way in which it's commonly used by most people, especially if the dictionary is willing to cede the point that literally now literally means figuratively as well as literally 🙄 but still, I am a strong proponent of logic and debate and enjoy taking the opportunity to point this out if only to raise awareness of logical fallacies)

Thank you for not being a climate change alarmist in your video. Far too many people react to change as a bad thing, but what they don't realize is that change is natural. The Sahara was a sea not so very long ago (in geologic terms), Antarctica has green grass and fresh water lakes trapped under the glaciers because it used to be temperate, and the Bonneville salt flats were once a vast lake as well.

Sure, it's inconvenient to have your house fall in, or a road buckle, etc... But we also shouldn't fool ourselves into thinking the world won't change under our feet, or that we can control the planet's thermostat. If the planet warms, we'll have to adapt. And if it cools, we'll have to adapt. In the end, we're just along for the ride, with almost no control over the planet's behavior.

I heard a very interesting story on NPR today about permafrost BURNING in Siberia. The crystal structure of permafrost ice is such that it retains a lot of oxygen. As a result, once it starts burning it can burn for months just on the methane content alone! Nothing we can do to stop it. Just extra emissions on top of an already stressed out planetary ecosystem.

Some really weird stuff going on in Siberian tundra too. They are not positive, but scientists think the large craters forming there are Methane caused explosions. While not confirmed, and there are dozens so far, all different from each other, a rapid venting of trapped Methane looks like cause. Explosion is probably cold rather than hot, meaning no ignition of Methane gas and resulting flames. More tests and samples are being collected.

Areas are very remote. More have been found by air than on foot. Population of Siberian Indigenous inhabitants is small compared to vastness of areas. Even people living there have never seen first hand any explosion, but have heard them. By the time they get to source of noise, crater is already there. Some large pieces of ice and still frozen tundra have been tossed hundreds of meters away. Some craters have a classic raise rim like from volcanic or meteoric impacts.

Raising temperatures and climate change is defiantly a candidate for the tipping event preceding explosions. Trapped Methane (there is huge resources of Methane in Russia) expand when temperatures rise. A cap of frozen tundra has kept Methane securely encapsulated. Rising temperatures soften tundra. Rising temperatures cause Methane gas pressures to rise. Eventually Methane gas is rapidly and explosively released.

Maybe they need to put lots of cameras with motion detection in areas. Might be able to capture an explosive event. They even put GPS and Cameras in Death Valley to solve mystery of the moving rocks at the 'racetrack'. They finally got the proof they were seeking. We would like to know if the Methane explosive events in Siberia are like Canaries in the Coal Mine of things to come.
